author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen, a Chart Powerhouse, Hits 10 Weeks at No. 1 (Again)
description: The country star’s latest album, “One Thing at a Time,” has fended off competition from Metallica, Ed Sheeran and several K-pop acts.
content: Two years ago, Morgan Wallen accomplished an extraordinary feat on the Billboard album chart. Primed as a crossover country star, he held the No. 1 spot for 10 consecutive weeks with his 30-song “Dangerous: The Double Album,” taking a page from the hip-hop playbook by stuffing his release with tracks to maximize the streaming yield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: The Wagner leader disputes a report that he offered to betray Russia.
description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military group, dismissed a report from The Washington Post saying that leaked intelligence showed he had offered to share Russian Army positions with Ukraine.
content: The head of the Wagner private military group on Monday rejected a report that he had offered to share with Ukraine the positioning of Russian Army troops around Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, in exchange for a withdrawal of Kyiv’s forces from the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Prosecutor Rebuts Trump’s Effort to Scuttle Elections Case
description: The prosecutor, Fani Willis, responded dismissively to a motion filed by Donald Trump’s lawyers that accused her of bias and sought to have her disqualified.
content: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., asked a judge to dismiss former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to have her disqualified from leading an investigation into whether he and his allies interfered in the 2020 election in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che and Olivia Wang
title: China Sentences a U.S. Citizen to Life in Prison for Espionage
description: A court in southeastern China handed down a guilty verdict to John Shing-Wan Leung, a Hong Kong resident, as the authorities ramp up a crackdown on spying.
content: A Chinese court said it sentenced a 78-year-old American citizen to life in prison on Monday on unspecified charges of spying, the latest in a wave of espionage cases the authorities have pursued amid growing wariness of foreign influence in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.9 Million Homes in California
description: A 1909 house in Echo Park, a storybook cottage in Mountain View and a new four-bedroom home in Monrovia.
content: This home is a mix of old and new: The living room and kitchen on the lower level were added in 2005; the rest of the house dates to the early 20th century and was moved to this site from Pasadena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: How Much Did Election Denial Hurt Republicans in the Midterms?
description: A new study by a nonpartisan group tries to put a number on that important question.
content: Denying the results of the 2020 election and casting doubts about the nation’s voting system cost statewide Republican candidates 2.3 to 3.7 percentage points in the midterms last year, according to a new study from States United Action, a nonpartisan group that promotes fair elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Vietnam Changed the Way This Jazz Man Heard the World
description: Henry Threadgill’s memoir unfolds from his maddening wartime experience to his boundary-pushing musical career
content: It’s rare to come across a new Vietnam War memoir from a major publisher in 2023. Most were written decades ago, when memories were fresh and wounds still raw. That generation of soldiers has begun to pass away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: What Chicago’s New Mayor Says About the City’s Biggest Challenges
description: Brandon Johnson, a progressive Democrat, explains how he plans to manage the nation’s third-largest city in a complicated moment.
content: It wasn’t long ago that Brandon Johnson, 47, was a county commissioner and teachers’ union organizer, unknown to many Chicagoans. On Monday he was sworn in as the city’s 57th mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 4, Episode 8 Recap: The Will of Some People
description: It’s election night in America. Stay away from the bodega sushi.
content: The day before Logan Roy died, he delivered a fiery call to arms to his ATN staff, letting them know what he expected from the network going forward. The speech was an angrier variation of the populist spiel he had given many times before, in which he insisted that the news should always be frank and unpretentious. He wanted his anchors to tell their viewers “truthful” things they had never heard anyone say before on television. He wanted ATN to be, in a word, “spicy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukrainians Send a Message With Their Bombs. On Them, Too.
description: Ukrainians have a lot to say to Russia, and many have chosen to say it in ink on the sides of rockets, mortar shells and even exploding drones.
content: The Ukrainian artilleryman was all set to slide the explosive shell into a launcher and send it on its way toward Russian positions — but first he had to take care of one last thing on his checklist.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 15, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 15, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes 2023: The Films We’re Excited About Seeing
description: Wes Anderson, Martin Scorsese and Todd Haynes have works premiering this year at the festival on the French Riviera.
content: Wes Anderson’s films have premiered at a wide variety of festivals, but after “Moonrise Kingdom” (2012), “The French Dispatch” (2021) and his upcoming ensemble comedy “Asteroid City,” Cannes is the fest he keeps coming back to. Last week, I asked Anderson what he finds so compelling about a debut on the Croisette.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: A U.S. Experiment on Single-Payer Care Just Ended
description: The system for one disease, Covid, had similarities to “Medicare for all.”
content: For the last three years, the United States has been operating an experiment in single-payer health care — for one disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Vice, Decayed Digital Colossus, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Vice, which had wooed media giants, has struggled to adjust to the punishing realities of digital publishing. A group of creditors could buy Vice for $225 million.
content: Vice Media filed for bankruptcy on Monday, punctuating a yearslong descent from a new-media darling to a cautionary tale of the problems facing the digital publishing industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Robinson and Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Ghosts of Beirut’ and ‘The Secrets of Hillsong’
description: A spy drama based on a decades-long manhunt comes to Showtime, and a new FX documentary brings back former Hillsong pastors to reflect on the church’s scandal.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Try a Churro Cone Filled With Soft Serve at Mercado Little Spain
description: Sip Athletic Brewing’s latest nonalcoholic release, consult an app with restaurant advice from professionals and more food news.
content: It’s been 10 years since Dominique Ansel created the Cronut sensation. Earlier this year, another croissant-style novelty appeared, this time at Mercado Little Spain, José Andrés’s food market in Hudson Yards. Xuxo is a traditional crunchy fried pastry from the Catalonian city of Girona, said the market’s head chef, Nicolás López. Mr. Andrés was taken with it at La Boqueria, the famous Barcelona market. For summer, at Mercado Little Spain, it has become xuxo helado, a churro-croissant cone sporting a generous topknot of soft-serve ($7). It can also be had with a cream, chocolate or strawberry filling ($5). As for the ice cream flavors, there are many, including strawberry, mango, Colacao (chocolate) and El Solero (mango swirl). But churros and ice cream are not a new pairing: Fany Gerson makes churro ice cream sandwiches that are sold on Goldbelly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: San Francisco Fed Ties to S.V.B. Chief Attracts Scrutiny to Century-Old Setup
description: As Greg Becker, the former C.E.O. of Silicon Valley Bank, prepares to testify before Congress, boards that oversee regional Federal Reserve branches are in the spotlight.
content: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has drawn attention to the relationship between the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, which was in charge of overseeing safety and soundness at the lender, and the bank’s former chief executive, Greg Becker, who for years sat on the San Francisco Fed’s board of directors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 8, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Boston Symphony Picks New Leader From Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: The departure of Chad Smith, the Philharmonic’s chief executive, is another loss for that orchestra, whose maestro, Gustavo Dudamel, is also leaving.
content: Chad Smith, a veteran arts leader who has helped turn the Los Angeles Philharmonic into one of the most innovative orchestras in the United States, will leave his post this fall to become president and chief executive of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, both ensembles announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Everybody Wants Victor Wembanyama. He Wants to Rule the N.B.A.
description: The 19-year-old French basketball star is the most hyped N.B.A. prospect since LeBron James, but he says he isn’t fazed by the pressure.
content: Boris Diaw was passing through Paris in late September and thought he would check out a basketball game. A young player he had heard about for years was playing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Graham-McLay
title: Fire at Hostel in New Zealand’s Capital Kills at Least 6
description: The cause of the blaze at the hostel, which has 92 rooms and no sprinklers, an official said, was under investigation.
content: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — At least six people were killed after a fire erupted overnight Tuesday in a hostel in Wellington, the capital of New Zealand, Prime Minister Chris Hipkins said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Anne Brown
title: Your DNA Can Now Be Pulled From Thin Air. Privacy Experts Are Worried.
description: Environmental DNA research has aided conservation, but scientists say its ability to glean information about human populations and individuals poses dangers.
content: David Duffy, a wildlife geneticist at the University of Florida, just wanted a better way to track disease in sea turtles. Then he started finding human DNA everywhere he looked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: If Your House Was Falling Off a Cliff, Would You Leave?
description: Homeowners along the eastern coast of England are watching the North Sea swallow their communities. Help is on the way — but only for some.
content: On a stormy day in the spring of 2021, the sea defenses on the beach below Lucy Ansbro’s cliff-top home in Thorpeness, England, washed away. Then, the end of her garden collapsed into the North Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: Durham Finds Fault With F.B.I. Over Russia Inquiry
description: The special counsel’s final report nevertheless did not produce blockbuster revelations of politically motivated misconduct, as Donald J. Trump and his allies had suggested it would.
content: John H. Durham, the Trump-era special counsel who for four years has pursued a politically fraught investigation into the Russia inquiry, accused the F.B.I. of having “discounted or willfully ignored material information” that countered the narrative of collusion between Donald J. Trump and Russia in a final report made public on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Title 42 Is Gone, but Not the Conditions Driving Migrants to the U.S.
description: Economic hardship, climate change, political instability and gang violence will continue to spur emigration from many corners of the world.
content: Relative quiet has prevailed along the southern U.S. border since Friday, despite widespread fears that ending a pandemic-era policy to immediately expel most migrants, even asylum seekers, would set off a stampede from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Hertz Apologizes After U.S. Citizen From Puerto Rico Is Denied Car Rental
description: Humberto Marchand was asked for his passport, though he produced a Puerto Rican driver’s license showing that he is from the U.S. territory. The rental company employee in Kenner, La., called the police.
content: Hertz, the rental car chain, has apologized after an employee refused to give a Puerto Rican man his prepaid reserved car at Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport because he presented a driver’s license issued on the island instead of a passport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Wu
title: The Loneliness, and Danger, of Being a Young Woman in a New City
description: In Bea Setton’s debut novel, “Berlin,” a 26-year-old protagonist moves into a German flat that is mysteriously attacked.
content: “Hunger was good discipline,” wrote Ernest Hemingway, who subsisted largely on alcohol when he lived in Paris. There, he visited the Musée du Luxembourg and communed with paintings by Cézanne that became “clearer and more beautiful if you were belly-empty, hollow-hungry.” Given the right combination of solitude and neglect, hunger can just as easily morph into self-deprivation. This proves true in “Berlin,” Bea Setton’s cinematic and confessional debut novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The $69 Billion Microsoft-Activision Deal Faces a Big E.U. Test
description: The bloc’s antitrust regulators could side with Microsoft on Monday, but the tech giant still faces an uphill battle to gaining full  approval.
content: European antitrust regulators are set to weigh in Monday on Microsoft’s $69 billion takeover of Activision Blizzard. In a twist, the European Commission is reportedly set to approve a video game megadeal that its American and British counterparts have already rejected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A Cancer Surgeon and Patient Is Biden’s Pick to Lead N.I.H.
description: President Biden said on Monday that he had selected Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, who has led the National Cancer Institute since October, to be the next director of the National Institutes of Health.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced on Monday that he would nominate Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, a cancer surgeon who became the director of the National Cancer Institute in October, to be the next director of the National Institutes of Health, filling a position that has been vacant for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong and Elian Peltier
title: Mysterious Killing of Chinese Gold Miners Puts New Pressure on Beijing
description: The massacre of nine workers in the Central African Republic and other recent attacks raise questions about China’s ability to protect its citizens overseas.
content: The Chinese embassy in the Central African Republic had a stark warning for its compatriots in the landlocked nation: Do not leave the capital city of Bangui. Kidnappings of foreigners were on the rise, and any Chinese person outside of Bangui was to leave those areas immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: A ‘Romeo and Juliet’ That Clowns Around With Tragedy
description: Directed by Hansol Jung and Dustin Wills, this sportive, vividly acted production fails to make a convincing case for its new gags and directorial flights.
content: “Romeo and Juliet” is at its core a cautionary tale of young love: Kiss a boy at a party one day, marry him the next, inside of a week you’re both dead. Of Shakespeare’s tragedies it is more propulsive than most, funnier and more modern, too, an amalgam of sex and death and a masquerade ball that requires little improvement. Cast a couple of charismatic leads, wind them up and let the bodies fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Abortion Showdown in North Carolina May Hinge on a Single Vote
description: After the G.O.P.-led legislature passed a 12-week ban, the Democratic governor vetoed the bill. The Republicans could override it, if all their members stay unified.
content: North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper, now in the waning years of his second term, has suddenly found himself back on a campaign trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: 16 Crucial Words That Went Missing From a Landmark Civil Rights Law
description: The phrase, seemingly deleted in error, undermines the basis for qualified immunity, the legal shield that protects police officers from suits for misconduct.
content: In a routine decision in March, a unanimous three-judge panel of a federal appeals court ruled against a Texas inmate who was injured when the ceiling of the hog barn he was working in collapsed. The court, predictably, said the inmate could not overcome qualified immunity, the much-criticized legal shield that protects government officials from suits for constitutional violations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen McElroy
title: Doyle Brunson, Poker Champion Known as ‘Texas Dolly,’ Dies at 89
description: In a lucrative career that began in the back rooms of Texas bars, he won back-to-back World Series of Poker titles (and 10 in all) and wrote a definitive poker manual.
content: Doyle Brunson, a champion poker player who, in a long, lucrative and colorful career with a deck of cards, won 10 World Series of Poker events, including two back-to-back titles, and influenced countless players with his definitive guide to Texas hold ’em and other games, died on Sunday in Las Vegas. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: dissipate
description: This word has appeared in 67 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word dissipate has appeared in 67 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 18 in “In a Treacherous Corner of Washington, a Classroom With 40-Foot Waves” by Kirk Johnson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachelle Bonja, Mary Wilson, Sydney Harper, Clare Toeniskoetter, Michael Benoist, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: The U.S. Banned Spyware — and Then Kept Trying to Use It
description: Inside the U.S. government’s double-edged relationship with the world’s most powerful and notorious hacking tool.
content: A little over a decade ago, a small Israeli company created what would become the world’s most powerful and notorious hacking tool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Why Some Countries Find It Hard to Move Away From Fossil Fuels
description: Trinidad and Tobago is the No. 2 exporter of liquefied natural gas in the Americas. Its output has been falling, but it remains committed to fossil fuels.
content: Ribboned shovel in hand, Prime Minister Keith Rowley joined a ceremonial groundbreaking last month to celebrate Trinidad and Tobago’s first large solar farm project expected to generate power for 42,000 homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Case for Journalistic Independence
description: The Times’s publisher makes the case for journalistic independence — and we give you the latest on Turkey’s election.
content: The subject of today’s newsletter is a bit different from normal. We’re going to focus on The Times itself — and how we define our mission today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Tony Awards Officials Ask Striking Writers to Reconsider Broadcast
description: The strike by the Writers Guild of America is endangering the June 11 broadcast of the Tony Awards, one of the biggest marketing opportunities for an industry recovering from the pandemic.
content: Tony Awards administrators held an emergency meeting on Monday to try to salvage this year’s ceremony in the face of a strike by screenwriters that is imperiling the broadcasting of the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Graduates, My Generation Wrecked So Much That’s Precious. How Can I Offer You Advice?
description: My only response is that age has exactly one advantage over the energy and brilliance of youth.
content: SEWANEE, Tenn. — Thirty-nine years ago, my college commencement was held in an un-air-conditioned gymnasium on the hottest day Alabama could serve up. I tried to talk my family into letting me skip the ceremony, but my grandmother, a retired schoolteacher, put her foot down. “We’re going,” she said. So we went. All I remember of the whole day is trying not to perish in the hallucinogenic heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Erdogan’s Grip on Power Is Loosened but Not Broken, Vote Shows
description: Despite a struggling economy, the disastrous earthquakes in February and Turkey’s drift toward one-man rule, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan was in the lead ahead of a runoff.
content: ANKARA, Turkey – Soaring inflation left his people feeling poorer. His government was accused of botching its response to catastrophic earthquakes that killed more than 50,000 people just three months ago. And he faced a newly unified opposition that promised to reverse his steady drift toward one-man rule.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: When Your Champions League Dream Runs Through a War Zone
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 15, 2023.
content: “For me, it was time to give back the love they gave me before.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ralph Nader and Others Clash Over the Value of Third Parties
description: Responses to a column by Gail Collins. Also: Officiants at weddings; a debt deal and gun control; helping Sherpas in Nepal.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan M. Jensen and Steven Pedigo
title: ­Why Laws Meant to Create Jobs Can Be So Destructive for Our Cities
description: How laws meant to inspire building things may incite destructive races to the bottom in places across the country.
content: President Biden and Vice President Harris recently announced their re-election campaign, with the president saying “Let’s finish this job.” Among the accomplishments they will be running on are the CHIPS and Science Act and the Inflation Reduction Act, which are designed to help the nation restore its domestic supply chain for semiconductors, promote renewable energy and improve climate resilience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: World Health Organization Warns Against Using Artificial Sweeteners
description: Continued consumption doesn’t reduce weight and could increase the risk of Type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and mortality in adults, the W.H.O. said on Monday.
content: The World Health Organization on Monday warned against using artificial sweeteners to control body weight or reduce the risk of noncommunicable diseases, saying that long-term use is not effective and could pose health risks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Possible Cyberattack Disrupts The Philadelphia Inquirer
description: The Inquirer, citing “anomalous activity” on its computer systems, said it was unable to print its regular Sunday edition and told staff members not to work in the newsroom at least through Tuesday.
content: A possible cyberattack on The Philadelphia Inquirer disrupted the newspaper’s print operation over the weekend and prompted it to close its newsroom through at least Tuesday, when its staff will be covering an expensive and fiercely contested mayoral primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: With a new tranche of weapons, Ukraine has much of what it needs for a counteroffensive, analysts say.
description: The additions to Ukraine’s arsenal, which include more tanks, drones and other weapons from Germany, may signal that Western officials believe Kyiv’s forces could reclaim significant swaths of territory.
content: The new long-range missiles, attack drones and tanks and other armored vehicles that President Volodymyr Zelensky has secured from allies in recent days will fulfill many, but not all, of the demands for weapons that Ukraine said it needs for a counteroffensive against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘Succession’ Style, Episode 8: Some People Just Can’t Cut a Deal
description: Tom is stressed in dress shoes, Shiv hides beneath layers (of lies and a turtleneck), and Willa cosplays as a first lady hopeful.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 8 of the final season of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Takes Up Case on Trump Hotel Records
description: The justices will decide whether individual House Democrats have standing to sue for documents concerning possible conflicts of interest.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would decide whether individual members of Congress are entitled to sue a government agency for information about a Washington hotel once owned by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Does the End of the Pandemic Emergency Mean to You?
description: On May 11, the U.S. government lifted its Covid-19 emergency. After more than three years of disruption and tragedy, resilience and change, we invite you to look back and reflect.
content: On May 5, the World Health Organization declared the end of the Covid-19 global health emergency. A week later, on March 11, the coronavirus public health emergency in the United States expired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: At the Real Embassy, Netflix’s ‘Diplomat’ Draws a Diplomatic Response
description: America’s ambassador to Britain says several top officials have called her to discuss the hit show, implausibilities and all. Now she’s meeting with Keri Russell, who plays her role.
content: This article includes spoilers for the Netflix series “The Diplomat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: A former U.S. Embassy employee is being held in Moscow, according to Russia’s state news agency.
description: The State Department had no immediate comment on the report that the man, identified as Robert Shonov, had been arrested and charged with conspiracy.
content: Robert Shonov, identified as a former employee of the U.S. Embassy in Russia, was arrested in the Russian city of Vladivostok and charged with conspiracy, according to the Russian state news agency Tass. The report did not identify his nationality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Despite Nazi Shadow, Jewelry Sale Sets $202 Million Record
description: The Christie’s auction had drawn criticism because it featured gems from the estate of a woman whose husband bought businesses from Jews pressured to sell because of Nazi persecution.
content: Criticism from historians and Jewish organizations did little to dim the sale at Christie’s of jewels bought with a fortune built in part atop profits made from the Aryanization of Jewish businesses during the Holocaust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman and Sasha Arutyunova
title: Hip-Hop’s Next Takeover: Quilts
description: Bisa Butler’s new show translates both photographs of Black figures and hip-hop lyrics into intricate textile art.
content: Art of Craft is a series about specialists whose work rises to the level of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Restaurant Service Charge Isn’t Going Anywhere
description: These added-on fees confuse diners and even employees, but more owners are relying on them to help make a tough business work.
content: Here’s a familiar restaurant scene: Dinner is over, the plates have been cleared and the server discreetly drops the bill on the table. But there’s something less familiar at the bottom of the check — a service charge, tacked on with little explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and April Rubin
title: 3 People Killed and 6 Injured in New Mexico Shooting
description: The shooter, an 18-year-old, was killed by the police, the authorities said. Two police officers were among the injured.
content: An 18-year-old gunman fired indiscriminately while roaming a residential street in Farmington, N.M., on Monday morning, killing three people before the police arrived and killed the suspect, the authorities said. Six other people, including two officers, were injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Signs Bill Defunding Diversity Spending in State Schools
description: The legislation is part of a broader Republican effort across the country to target D.E.I. programs.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis signed legislation on Monday that largely banned Florida’s public universities and colleges from spending money on diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives and imposed other measures that could reshape higher education at state schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What to Know About the N.B.A. Draft Lottery
description: A draw on Tuesday in Chicago will determine the order for the first 14 picks in the 2023 draft, which will be held in June.
content: Fans of the N.B.A. are about to take a break from praying that a wild, off-balance 3-pointer goes in and instead turn to praying that a particular envelope happens to contain the logo of their favorite team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitchell Abidor and Miguel Lago
title: Why Is France Acting Like Marine Le Pen Is the Adult in the Room?
description: Shouldn’t a protest movement led by unions be benefiting the left?
content: For three months, France has been in revolt: Demonstrators have marched; railroad workers have blocked tracks; barricades and buildings have been set aflame; protesters have done battle in the street with police. The most recent innovation has been tamer: People have banged pots whenever the president has appeared. The cause? President Emmanuel Macron’s measure raising the retirement age from 62 to 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Six-Hour Opera Goes On for One Euphoric Night Only
description: “Stranger Love,” a singular and hypnotic work by Dylan Mattingly and Thomas Bartscherer, opens (and closes) on Saturday in Los Angeles.
content: Years ago, when the composer Dylan Mattingly was at work on a new project, he wrote to his collaborator, Thomas Bartscherer, telling him, “I often find that *really* long is better than just long.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Raichlen
title: This Tool Pushes the Limits of Outdoor Cooking
description: The big grilling manufacturers have turned to griddles, which let the backyard chef tackle projects grill grates cannot handle.
content: In the early 2000s, Roger Dahle attended an outdoor pancake breakfast cooked on a commercial flattop at his local Rotary Club, a civic organization, in Utah. “I love cooking breakfast outdoors, but you couldn’t buy an outdoor griddle for home use,” Mr. Dahle said. So the entrepreneur set out to create one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Eric Adams’s Transition Team Is Fined $19,600 for Violations
description: The fines represent the first time the New York City Campaign Finance Board has issued a financial penalty to a mayoral transition team.
content: Mayor Eric Adams’s mayoral transition committee was fined $19,600 on Monday for violating New York City’s campaign finance rules — the first time in the city’s history that the Campaign Finance Board has levied a financial penalty on a mayoral transition committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gulsin Harman and Ben Hubbard
title: Four Takeaways From Turkey’s Nail-Biting Presidential Election
description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan is headed for his — and his country’s — first presidential runoff vote. But the first round showed the longtime leader’s continued strength.
content: Turkey’s nail-biter election will go to a runoff, election officials announced on Monday, extending a pivotal vote that has demonstrated that the incumbent, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is still a formidable political force, despite his failure to secure a first-round victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the P.G.A. Championship, Justin Thomas Looks for Last Year’s Magic
description: The defending champion comes to Oak Hill without finishing first in any of the 20 events he has entered since claiming his second career major victory in 2022.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Five years ago, when Justin Thomas came to the 2018 P.G.A. Championship as the defending champion, he was still cruising along as one of the top three players in the game and had spent a stint as the top-ranked men’s golfer in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Hotels Roll Out the Red Carpet for Pets
description: Doggy menus, plush beds, nose balm and pet sitting: As people increasingly travel with their four-legged friends, hotels are stepping up with more amenities.
content: If you wouldn’t dream of going on vacation without your pet, you’re in luck. Hotels and resorts are increasingly catering to them with new packages and amenities (or “pet-menities,” as Virgin Hotels puts it), be it an in-room dining menu for dogs with a “beef woofslider” at Andaz Mexico City Condesa, or a posh pet blanket made of recycled wool from one of the Marine & Lawn Hotels & Resorts in Britain. Perks abound, like “puppuccinos” at the Omni La Costa Resort & Spa in Carlsbad, Calif., and paw-and-nose balm at the Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: After Decades of Drinks and Laughs, Is It Last Call at the Friars Club?
description: The New York headquarters of the legendary entertainment fraternity is facing the threat of foreclosure as its leaders look for a buyer willing to help keep the party going.
content: One of the final episodes of “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” released this month, captured the bawdy, profanity-laced ritual that was a celebrity roast at New York’s Friars Club — the kind of entertainment that helped make the club the buzzing epicenter of the comedy world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Mutation Protected Man From Alzheimer’s Disease, Hinting at Treatment
description: A man in his early 40s showed physical signs of the illness, but didn’t develop symptoms until he was nearly 70 because of a protective gene.
content: The man should have gotten Alzheimer’s disease in his early 40s — he had a gene mutation that guaranteed it, or so it seemed. Scans of his brain even revealed severe atrophying and the hallmarks of the disease: rough, hard, amyloid plaques and spaghetti-like tangles of tau proteins. But the fatal brain disease did not appear until the man was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Cranor
title: One Punch Later and Belfast Pulls Him Back
description: In Michael Magee’s visceral debut novel, “Close to Home,” a young man commits an assault that jeopardizes his plans for the future.
content: Though the voice is decidedly Irish, the message of Michael Magee’s dead-on debut novel is universal. At its core, “Close to Home” is about finding a way to transcend the pain, the people and the place you’re born into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Visiting the Migrant Camp at the San Diego-Tijuana Border
description: A sprawling and stunningly diverse camp has sprung up this month along California’s southern border.
content: SAN DIEGO — At California’s southern border, two parallel, towering fences stretch for miles, their reddish steel beams cutting through rugged hillsides thick with tall stalks of yellow wildflowers and marking where Mexico ends and the United States begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned Through a Quarter of the M.L.B. Season
description: The Mets have struggled (but may be fine), stolen bases are cool again (but runners, beware), and it’s too early to judge (most of) the off-season’s free-agent signings.
content: There is no question that this season will go down in history as the one in which the pitch clock changed baseball. Whether it is also the season that saved baseball is too soon to tell, but the pitch clock’s effect is real: With around a quarter of the season complete, the average game is 27 minutes shorter than it was last season and the percentage of games lasting longer than 3 hours 30 minutes has fallen off a cliff, to 0.4 percent, after having been higher than 10 percent in five of the previous six seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Suhasini Raj
title: Cyclone Mocha Leaves Thousands Homeless in Bangladesh and Myanmar
description: There was less damage than predicted, but the Rohingya refugee camps on the coast of Bangladesh, where most live in simple shanties, were hit particularly hard.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people began repairing or rebuilding their homes and livelihoods on Monday after a deadly cyclone hit Myanmar and Bangladesh over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. Acknowledges Black Americans Face More Audit Scrutiny
description: The commissioner, Daniel Werfel, said the agency was working to correct unfairness in the enforcement of the tax code.
content: The Internal Revenue Service said on Monday that Black taxpayers have been far more likely to be audited than others and that it is considering changes to its case selection process to address discrimination in how the tax code is enforced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Mexico’s Lavish Presidential Plane Arrives at Its New Home in Tajikistan
description: Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the president of Mexico, who had called the jet an example of excess, had spent years trying to find a suitor for it.
content: A plane that Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the president of Mexico, once described as an “insult to the people” arrived in Tajikistan on Monday, he said, completing the sale of the jet to that country’s government and delivering on a campaign promise to do away with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: The Best and Worst Habits for Eyesight
description: Are carrots good? Is blue light bad? Experts weigh in on nine common beliefs.
content: If you were ever scolded as a child for reading in the dark, or if you have used blue-light-blocking glasses when working on a computer, you might have incorrect ideas about eye health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: In ‘Succession,’ Democracy Goes Up in Smoke
description: On Sunday night, the Roys pondered whether to sell out democracy in exchange for their father’s kingdom. In the real world, the going rate is usually cheaper.
content: This article includes spoilers for the most recent episode of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Upheaval in Teaching Reading
description: New York City students are struggling with reading, but principals are worried that the rollout of a new teaching method is happening too quickly.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at something so fundamental it’s the first of the three R’s — and why New York City is about to change the way it is taught in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Striking Hollywood Writers Disrupt TV’s Major Ad Event
description: Dozens of protesters greeted marketers as they entered the first major event of the upfronts, an annual showcase for advertisers in which media companies stage lavish gatherings to promote their lineups.
content: As scores of marketers made their way to Radio City Music Hall on Monday morning for a major event hosted by NBCUniversal, they were greeted by dozens of striking writers marching near the entrances to the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Results of Turkey’s election.
content: Turkey’s presidential election appears to be destined for a runoff after the incumbent, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, failed to win a majority of the vote, in the toughest political challenge of his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: At 81, Martha Stewart Is the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue Cover Star
description: The domestic diva talks about shedding her inhibitions, and (most of) her clothes, for the cover shoot.
content: It’s useless to try to pigeonhole Martha Stewart. Decorously entertaining homemaker-slash-lifestyle guru, television personality, publisher, canny entrepreneur-turned-white-collar criminal, Snoop Dogg’s unlikely BFF — these are labels she spins, or drops when it suits her, as adroitly as a juggler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: E.U. Approves Microsoft’s $69 Billion Deal for Activision
description: The green light follows objections to the blockbuster deal by American and British regulators on the grounds that it would undercut competition.
content: Microsoft’s faltering $69 billion bid to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard received a glimmer of hope on Monday when European Union regulators approved what would be the largest consumer tech deal in two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: No Degree? No Problem. Biden Tries to Bridge the ‘Diploma Divide.’
description: President Biden is trying to appeal to working-class voters by emphasizing his plans to create well-paid jobs that do not require a college degree.
content: When President Biden told a crowd of union workers this year that every American should have a path to a good career — “whether they go to college or not” — Tyler Wissman was listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Hiba Yazbek
title: In First, Palestinian Displacement Commemorated at United Nations
description: The event, marking the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians when Israel was created, was condemned by the Israeli ambassador to the world body.
content: NEW YORK — The United Nations for the first time on Monday officially commemorated the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in the war surrounding the creation of Israel 75 years ago, drawing a sharp response from the Israeli ambassador to the world body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan and Asmaa Elkeurti
title: A Crumbling New York Garage Collapsed. Dozens More Have Similar Problems.
description: The fatal failure of a building in Lower Manhattan raised questions about the state of parking structures across New York. Records and interviews reveal some answers.
content: After a parking garage collapsed in Lower Manhattan last month, killing one person and injuring five others, officials scrambled to check dozens of other garages across the city for structural problems that could cause another disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karla Cornejo Villavicencio
title: Immigrants Keep Loving America, Even When America Doesn’t Love Them Back
description: I was undocumented for 25 years, and I am a child of immigrants who remain undocumented.
content: I know all too well how some Americans feel about immigrants: I was undocumented for 25 years, and I am a child of immigrants who remain undocumented. I also wrote a book about the daily lives of migrants during the Trump years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Remy Tumin and Stephanie Lai
title: Staff Members Attacked With Bat at Congressman’s Virginia Office
description: Two people were hospitalized after the attack at the Fairfax office of Representative Gerald E. Connolly, a Democrat. A man was in custody, the police said.
content: A man armed with a baseball bat and demanding to see Representative Gerald E. Connolly, Democrat of Virginia, attacked and injured two staff aides in a rampage inside the congressman’s Fairfax, Va., office, the latest episode in a surge of political violence across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Jonathan Wolfe
title: What’s Next for Turkey?
description: Also, college graduates flee coastal cities. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Turkey’s nail-biter of an election will go to a runoff, officials said, as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan showed he was still a formidable political force. Although he fell just short of an outright majority, with 49.5 percent of the vote, signs point strongly to yet another Erdogan victory in two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn Cohen
title: Alan Ruck Is Ready to Leave the Roy Family
description: As “Succession” nears its end, the veteran actor is looking forward to closing the book on Connor Roy.
content: The article includes spoilers for the most recent episode of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Reiterates That the U.S. Could Run Out of Cash by June 1
description: The latest warning to Congress came before another meeting on Tuesday between President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy to resolve the debt ceiling crisis.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen reiterated on Monday that the United States could run out of money to pay its bills by June 1 if Congress does not raise or suspend the debt limit, adding to the pressure on President Biden and congressional leaders as they race to reach an agreement to avert a default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juston Jones and Vivian Wang
title: World leaders in Japan, China as a negotiator, and grain deal deadline: What to watch for this week.
description: While the battle for Bakhmut, a mostly ruined city where tens of thousands of soldiers are believed to have died, continues to rage after Ukraine made some gains for the first time in months, world leaders are planning several efforts in the coming days to find new diplomatic avenues for ending the war.
content: While the battle for Bakhmut, a mostly ruined city where tens of thousands of soldiers are believed to have died, continues to rage after Ukraine made some gains for the first time in months, world leaders are planning several efforts in the coming days to find new diplomatic avenues for ending the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How Parents Can Actually Help Teens Navigate Social Media
description: The American Psychological Association has urged parents to monitor adolescents for “problematic” social media use. We asked experts for some realistic and effective ways to do this.
content: The American Psychological Association issued its first-ever guidance on social media use in adolescence last week, a roundup of 10 recommendations for educators, policymakers, tech companies and parents aimed at helping teens engage with the technology in a safe and positive way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: An Unsigned Postcard Named Four Family Members Who Died in the Holocaust. Why?
description: The mysterious card, from 2003, is at the center of Anne Berest’s book, which is part detective story, part examination of French attitudes toward Judaism.
content: In 2003, an unsigned postcard reached the Berest family home. On one side was an old picture of the Opéra Garnier. On the other, there were four names: Ephraïm. Emma. Noémie. Jacques. All were relatives of the French author Anne Berest. All died in Auschwitz in 1942.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
title: Japan Is Unmasking, and Its Smile Coach Is Busy
description: After three years of Covid-era masking, some Japanese people feel their facial expressions are a bit rusty. Enter Keiko Kawano, smile instructor.
content: About six years ago, Keiko Kawano, a radio host, found that when she stopped doing voice-articulation exercises, her smile began to fade. At a certain point, she struggled to lift the corners of her mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Are Americans So Negative About the Economy?
description: It’s an interesting question, given that the economy is actually looking remarkably strong.
content: Almost a year has passed since the Bureau of Economic Analysis announced that the U.S. economy had contracted for two quarters in a row. Some people believe, wrongly, that two quarters of falling G.D.P. is the official definition of a recession. Economic negativity ran rampant, especially but not only on the political right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Catie Edmondson
title: Biden Expresses Optimism on Debt Limit, but a Deal Remains Elusive
description: President Biden and congressional leaders will resume face-to-face talks on Tuesday to raise the debt limit and avoid a default.
content: President Biden and congressional leaders will resume face-to-face talks on Tuesday to avert a government default, with the White House expressing cautious optimism as the contours of a possible deal began to come into focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In European Tour, Zelensky Reaps Billions More in Promised Military Aid
description: His trips to Britain, Germany, France and Italy demonstrated the shifting political landscape when it comes to supporting Kyiv, as concerns grow about U.S. backing as the presidential election looms.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has been promised billions of dollars in new military aid during a whirlwind tour of European allies that reflects a striking shift in the political landscape, as Europe takes a more central role in arming Ukraine for its anticipated counteroffensive to drive Russia from its territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Upgrade My Carhartt Wardrobe?
description: A reader wonders how to spruce up a closet full of “drab Pacific Northwest earth tones.”
content: It should not be news to you, but if Carhartt is your default, you are way ahead of the game. Carhartt is, by pretty much any measure, cool these days. Or maybe hot is a better word? Public figures including Senator John Fetterman and ASAP Rocky are fans, and brands like Marni and Junya Watanabe are jumping at the chance for a collaboration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Runoff in Turkey
description: Also, Thailand’s opposition parties agreed to form a coalition.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan failed to secure a first-round victory in Turkey’s presidential election and will now face a runoff on May 28. Still, he seems well positioned to win another five-year term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Dyja
title: The History of Hong Kong Is One of Bridged Divides
description: In “Fortune’s Bazaar,” Vaudine England rejects a tale-of-two-cities approach to the history of Hong Kong’s colonization, embracing the in-between lives of those who made it.
content: I love every word of “A Tale of Two Cities.” The story, the characters, “it is a far, far better thing that I do” — all so dramatic and heartbreaking. I just wish Charles Dickens had come up with a different title. Yes, it’s brilliant, those T’s lined up rat-a-tat-tat; but in the 160 or so years since it was published, “A Tale of Two Cities” has become the speech- or opinion writer’s lazy metaphor of choice for the inequities of a particular city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
title: A Top Japanese Talent Agency Apologizes Amid Sexual Abuse Accusations
description: The chief executive of the agency said she had not been aware of the claims against the agency’s founder, despite years of them coming to light.
content: One of Japan’s most influential entertainment production companies has issued an apology over sexual assault claims leveled against its founder, Johnny Kitagawa, decades after allegations about abuse of young men in his care first came to light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Cannot Be Unseen
description: Just when you thought things couldn’t get stranger or sadder.
content: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, good to be conversing again. Heck of a lot going on. Before we get to the border or the budget, though, let me admit I’m shallow and start with the Trump town hall on CNN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Would You Include Skims in Your Wedding?
description: Some women are saying “I would” to Kim Kardashian’s newest collection for her shapewear brand, which features something new and blue (and, of course, white).
content: Kim Kardashian’s shapewear brand Skims has developed a cult following for its everyday basics and intimates and its neutral color palette — so much so that it has inspired a subgenre of “Skims dupes and alternatives.” Customer favorites include a form-fitting maxi lounge dress that drapes down the body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and María Magdalena Arréllaga
title: One Secret to a Latin American Party’s Dominance: Buying Votes
description: In Paraguay, the Colorado Party has held power for seven decades. On Election Day, it rounds up Indigenous people and pays them for their votes.
content: The Espinillo Indigenous community is 13 miles from the nearest polling station — and no one in the village has a car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Chloë Sevigny Sold Her Old Clothes, and People Came in Droves
description: Fashion lovers flocked to shop from the star’s collection of garments in what was advertised on social media as the “sale of the century.”
content: For a certain kind of fashion fiend, it was a dream: shop the actress Chloë Sevigny’s closet, with her present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Consider South Carolina Voting Map Ruled a Racial Gerrymander
description: A unanimous three-judge panel found that a congressional voting district anchored in Charleston, S.C., violated the Constitution’s equal protection clause.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would decide whether a congressional voting district in South Carolina should be restored after a lower court struck it down as an unconstitutional racial gerrymander.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: ‘Antigone in the Amazon’ Review: The Drama Is Brazil’s Land War
description: The Swiss director Milo Rau drapes a traumatic episode of Brazilian history with a Greek tragedy on a Belgian stage.
content: GHENT, Belgium — You can’t say the Swiss theater director Milo Rau doesn’t practice what he preaches. Art and activism are deeply intertwined in his work: As part of his “trilogy of ancient myths,” he rehearsed and filmed part of an adaptation of Aeschylus’ “Oresteia” in Iraq in 2019. In the next installment, “The New Gospel,” inspired by the life of Jesus, he staged a film, using refugees in Matera, Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Look at the Fed’s Likely Next No. 2
description: Philip Jefferson’s speeches offer insight into how rate setters think about fighting inflation.
content: Philip Jefferson, an economist who joined the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors in May 2022, was nominated by President Biden on Friday to be its vice chair. I didn’t write about his appointment last year; his proposed elevation gives me a second chance to discuss his ideas. There’s more to chew on now: The Fed website has six speeches he’s given since joining the board on such topics as inflation, inclusive economic growth and technology’s impact on the postpandemic economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Clever Upgrades to Comfort Classics
description: Carrot cake cupcakes with not-too-sweet frosting, a no-cans chicken casserole and Spanish-style French toast cooked on a griddle.
content: There are two kinds of carrot cake. The first, often found next to the bran muffins, emphasizes the carrot as vegetable and icing as frippery to be rationed, and firmly declares itself to be a healthful baked good. The second uses the carrot as an alibi for a generous spackling of cream cheese frosting so sugary that even my overly enthusiastic sweet tooth aches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiff Fehr
title: Finding Order in a Thicket of Nonprofit Data
description: To investigate the practices of a group of political nonprofits, we first needed to conquer a pesky foil of data journalists: the PDF.
content: Data journalists such as myself struggle with one ever-present challenge: working with PDFs, the portable document formats unleashed by Adobe in the 1990s that are now ubiquitous barnacles on our digital lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Gopnik
title: What We Lose When We Push Our Kids to ‘Achieve’
description: The sense of happiness that comes from absorption in a thing we are truly drawn to can be discovered but not taught.
content: When I was 12, I disappeared into my bedroom with a $40 folk guitar and a giant book of Beatle songs, with elementary, large-type “E-Z” chord diagrams to follow. I had no musical gift, as a series of failed music lessons had assured me — it was actually the teachers who assured me; the lessons were merely dull — and no real musical training. My fingers stung as I tried to press down on the strings without making them buzz, and my left hand ached as I tried, and for a long time failed, stretching it across the neck. Nonetheless, I worked my way through “Rain” (abbreviated to two chords) and “Love Me Do” (three) and finally “Yellow Submarine” (four chords, or was it five?) and discovered by myself the matchless thrill of homemade musical harmony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Niraj Chokshi
title: U.S.-Made Technology Is Flowing to Russian Airlines, Despite Sanctions
description: Russian customs data shows that millions of dollars of aircraft parts made by Boeing, Airbus and others were sent to Russia last year.
content: Last August, Oleg Patsulya, a Russian citizen living near Miami, emailed a Russian airline that had been cut off from Western technology and materials with a tempting offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: New Coalition in Thailand Challenges Military Rule After Election
description: Thais voted overwhelmingly for change on Sunday, but the military-appointed Senate could still block the opposition’s nomination for prime minister.
content: The two opposition parties that won the largest share of the vote in Thailand’s general election over the weekend said on Monday that they had agreed to form a coalition government. It remained unclear, however, whether the ruling junta would hand over power easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Climate Change Brings Warmer, Wetter Weather to Trinidad
description: Even as the leaders of Trinidad and Tobago double down on fossil fuels, climate change is bringing more extreme weather to the island nation.
content: Imtiaz Khan remembers the rains of his childhood as being light and providing welcome relief from the summer heat. A heavy shower, he said, would arrive only about once a month during the rainy season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Best Mother's Day Brunch Recipes
source.name: The New York Times

title: J. Smith-Cameron on the Key to Gerri on ‘Succession’
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Simple and Surprising Nutrition Tips
source.name: The New York Times

title: This Mysterious Spiral in the Alaska Sky Had an Earthly Explanation
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: What If Instead of Trying to Manage Your Time, You Set It Free?
description: The cultural critic Jenny Odell sees a way out of our obsession with personal efficiency.
content: The cultural critic Jenny Odell sees a way out of our obsession with personal efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kristin Chenoweth Is at Home on a Big Broadway Stage
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Clean Bathroom Tile and Grout
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the Titles of 13 Pulitzer Prize Winners Hidden in This Text?
description: Last week’s Pulitzer Prize announcement added several new books to the long list of winners — and this month’s Title Search puzzle challenges you to find a baker’s dozen of previous recipients hiding in plain sight.
content: Last week’s Pulitzer Prize announcement added several new books to the long list of winners — and this month’s Title Search puzzle challenges you to find a baker’s dozen of previous recipients hiding in plain sight.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Takes Its Final Curtsy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: Turkey Election Maps: Why Erdogan Is Headed For a Runoff
description: Maps show how every province in Turkey voted so far. Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s longtime leader, was headed to a presidential election runoff for the first time.
content: Maps show how every province in Turkey voted so far. Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Turkey’s longtime leader, was headed to a presidential election runoff for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger, Robert Gebeloff and Josh Katz
title: Coastal Cities Priced Out Low-Wage Workers. Now College Graduates Are Leaving, Too.
description: Educated workers are increasingly migrating away from the country’s most expensive major metros — and have been since before the pandemic.
content: Educated workers are increasingly migrating away from the country’s most expensive major metros — and have been since before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Spaghetti Carbonara Recipe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Cyclone Leaves Path of Destruction Across Bangladesh and Myanmar
description: A cyclone called Mocha damaged several buildings in Myanmar and tore through bamboo shanties in refugee camps in Bangladesh.
content: A cyclone called Mocha damaged several buildings in Myanmar and tore through bamboo shanties in refugee camps in Bangladesh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Victory Eludes Erdogan as Turkey Presidential Election Heads to Runoff
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey failed to win a majority of the vote, setting the stage for a runoff against Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the main opposition candidate.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey failed to win a majority of the vote, setting the stage for a runoff against Kemal Kilicdaroglu, the main opposition candidate.
source.name: The New York Times
